bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank Carey, June 6, 1950

div1.p: Hench sends Carey reprints of his articles on the yellow fever story. He provides a detailed account of his involvement in researching the story and his attempts to preserve Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank Carey, June 6, 1950
div1.opener:
June 6, 1950
Mr. Frank Carey
Science Reporter
330 Star Building
Washington 4, D. C.
My dear Mr. Carey:
div1.p:
By separate post I am sending you three reprints that I have written
on the yellow fever story. While Each one is a little different; one has
material in it that the others do not have. The reprint of the Fourth Inter-
national Congress on Malaria and Tropical Medicine has some historical para-
graphs in it that are not available elsewhere. The story of how I found the
lost Camp Lazear is given in the Pharos for May 1948. I enclose also a pro-
gram of the unveiling of the bust and tablet of Walter Reed in the Hall of
Fame. The letters reprinted there are all in my possession as Mrs. Reed and
the Reed family have given me everything, letters, pamphlets, clippings, etc.,
that they had, including the Congressional Medal and I have added to this
large collection other material which I have gotten from many sources, in-
cluding many of the surviving participants of the experiments.

I am delighted that you are writing a story as this is the 50th
anniversary of the conquest of yellow fever by Reed and his colleagues.

You ask how I became interested in the subject. Very briefly, it
was this. Doctor Lazear was a graduate of Washington and Jefferson College,
Washington, Pennsylvania, a small college that is the oldest one west of
the Allogheny Mountains. I did not graduate from that college but in about
1938, Washington and Jefferson planned to erect a memorial building in honor
of Doctor Lazear, their distinguished alumnus. It so happened that the Presi-
dent of W & J at that time was Dr. Ralph Hutchison, one of my oldest friends
who often visits me in Rochester. One evening he was telling me about their
plans and said he wanted to arrange a very attractive program on the occasion
of the dedication. He said that they wanted to honor not only Doctor Lazear
but the entire medical profession and that they would like to have two dis-
tinguished speakers of international repute, one representing surgery and the
other medicine. His idea was to invite Dr. W. J. Mayo as an American surgeon
and Lord Dawson (King George's physician) as an internationally known physician.
We saw Doctor Will who agreed to participate and later that year I went to
Europe on another mission and presented to Lord Dawson the invitation. However,
the next year Doctor Will died and of course the war came to England.

But to go back a bit, the night in my home that Doctor Hutchison
brought up the matter of the dedication program he said he wanted to have
some human interest in the program and was hoping that he could find some
Mr. Frank Carey
- 2 -
June 6, 1950
of the surviving doctors but he was afraid they were all dead. I remembered
the story of Walter Reed from my medical school days but know nothing about
who the volunteers were or whether they were alive or dead but I did sug-
gest that if the principals were dead, that is the doctors, why not get one
or two of the human guinea pigs. To this Doctor Hutchison replied “That
would be a find idea, Phil. As your contribution to the program will you
find out who they were, which ones are alive and where they live?” Rather
glibly I accepted this task.

Within the next week I read Kelly's book on Walter Reed and found
a few of the names but had no idea how to go about finding out whether they
were alive or dead but my first bit of luck came to me about two weeks later when
I heard announced on the radio program of “We, the People” the statement that
the dramatization of the story of the conquest of yellow fever would be given
the following week with one of the survivors being also on the program. I
listened to the program. It was Kissinger. I got in touch with him through
the radio station and later visited him at his home. I assumed that the whole
story had been told but to my surprise I found that Kissinger had never written
down of his own personal experiences although he had frequently given them
extemporaneously before small groups. Kissinger was a fine fellow but not
well educated. I made many notes and later got him to Rochester as my guest
and got a pretty complete story from him.

He gave me the news of a few of the survivors, chief of whom was
Johnny Moran of Havana, Cuba. Mrs. Hench and I often go to Florida for
Winter vacations so in the spring of 1940 Mrs. Hench and I went to Cuba from
Florida to visit Johnny. I found from him also that the correct story had
never been told but equally thrilling was the re-discovery of the lost Camp
Lazear, the story of which is given in the Pharos for May 1948.

Through these two contacts I got slowly the addresses of all the
survivors or their relatives and have visited practically all of them. We
have uncovered in attics and cellars long lost records. I have spent
literally days in the National Archives in Washington uncovering old records
and have a voluminous series of 30 files bulging with unpublished data which,
sometime when I retire, I hope to write up. But the important features of
the story are as given in these reprints.

I have spent a great deal of time patiently trying to stimulate the
Cubans to help preserve Building No. 1. Just before the war, through the
courtesy of the owner of the property, I was given a deed to the little building
but the proviso was that my plans would be completed in a year or two. The war
interrupted this so that my deed lapsed. However I was able to stimulate the
Cuban Government to declare the little building a national memorial. I tried to
collect some money in this country. I interviewed Nelson Rockefeller on one
occasion and later interviewed the Finance Secretary of John D. Rockefeller, Jr.
They were not interested. I thought they would be because of the extensive
interest of the Rockefeller Foundation in Latin America and particularly in
yellow fever control. Two years ago I visited Cuba again and found that
although the Cuban Government had set aside the building nominally as a
national monument, they had done absolutely nothing toward preserving it.
Mr. Frank Carey
- 3 -
June 6, 1950
It is falling to pieces, and has, miraculously, survived several tornadoes.
I went to several authorities, including the Vice President, who kindly
received me in his home and we spent the evening going over a plan which
I had worked out with two or three important Cuban physicians to build
around Building No. 1 for a helth center for the community of Quemados.
I thought the cost of the modest plan would be $50,000 to $100,000. Every-
one concerned approved the plan heartily but knowing the “manana” attitude
of the Cubans, I begged to be allowed to surround Building No. 1 with a
galvanized protection at my expense. But with the usual Latin politeness,
they wouldn't listen to such a thing and the Vice-President insisted that
the Government would take care of the matter. Within a few weeks the
Government did allocate $50,000 for protecting the building and laying out
the grounds. I saw the announcement of the passage of the bill in the
Cuban papers and there was a little advertisement with newspaper photographs
of the little building. But thereafter, as has happened to me several times
before, those who promised these things were swept out of office and nothing
has happened.

Actually, the naming of the building as a historical monument has
done nothing but interfere because otherwise I, as a private citizen with
two or three other prominent sympathetic Cubans, could go ahead and make
arrangements for protecting the little building with a galvanized iron
covering until the full plans could be carried out.

I have talked to the Surgeon General of the Army about this. He is
most sympathetic with my plan but of course has himself no power to help ex-
cept to recomment. I thought that the U. S. Army might make a gesture of
help combining efforts with the State Department. It would be a splendid
thing if some american could cooperate with this venture and, among other
things, build up friendship by doing away with the most unfortunate spat
among the Cubans who think that the Americans and Reed robbed Finlay of
just credit. Several years ago when Mr. Louis Johnson was a patient here
and was, I think, an under-secretary of some sort in Washington, he heard
me give an illustrated lecture on this subject. He sent me a note saying
that if he could help at any time he would be glad to do so. Somewhat in
desperation, therefore, about a month ago, when he was here for a brief
visit, I reminded him of that, told him briefly of my plan and wondered
whether the Government could be persuaded to allocate $50,000. His reply
was brief and short “Not this year. We must out down all possible ex-
penses. Perhaps next year would be a better time.” That is where the
matter stands and it is a darn shame. I haven't had the time to go out
and collect nickels and I haven't found a millionaire with $50,000 or $100,000
and yet here a little building which saw one of the most dramatic adventures
in history is being allowed to rot.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
P.S.: Perhaps your own article might get some sympathetic readers. I wish it would.
I have your letter of June 2. I “rented” the drawing of the Yellow
Fever Epidemic in Shreveport from the Bettman Archives, 211A East 57th Street,
New York. They rent you a print for $5 or $10 and you are supposed to send it
back and you have to give credit to them. I am glad to send you a print of
Building No. 1. How soon would you need this? Our photographic department
Mr. Frank Carey
- 4 -
June 6, 1950
is completely swamped making last-minute photographs, slides and movies for
the meeting of the American Medical Association in three weeks. Could you
possibly wait until after then? If not, will you allow me to borrow the
negative and have the print made (at a small cost) by some photographer
here in town. The Clinic does not want us to send the negative out of town
and this one now belongs to the Clinic collection.
